+tirendir
As stated last night, here are my rebuttals to arguments made in your 
comments:

1. Your 1st comment - "...and it can be easily argued that carbon dating is 
both inaccurate and unreliable."  
True, it can. Unfortunately, this does not mean that these arguments are 
right. The decay rates observed across a multitude of radioactive isotopes 
have been proven to be both accurate and reliable. The following 2 lists 
represent a small portion of known half-lifes for a number of radioactive 
isotopes:
isotope         half-life (days)
vanadium-48         15.9735     
californium-253     17.81     
chromium-51         27.7025     
mendelevium-258     51.5     
beryllium-7         53.12     
californium-254     60.5     
cobalt-56         77.27     
scandium-46         83.79     
sulfur-35         87.32     
thulium-168         93.1     
fermium-257         100.5     
thulium-170         128.6     
polonium-210         138     
cobalt-57         271.79     
vanadium-49         330     
californium-248     333.5     

isotope         half-life (years)
ruthenium-106         1.023     
neptunium-235         1.084     
cadmium-109         1.267     
thulium-171         1.92     
caesium-134         2.0652     
sodium-22         2.602     
rhodium-101         3.3     
cobalt-60         5.2714     
hydrogen-3         12.32     
californium-250     13.08     
niobium
meta state Nb-93m     16.13     
strontium-90         28.79     
curium-243         29.1     
caesium-137         30.17

Clearly, each of these is observable within a single human lifetime; far 
more than the "minimum of no less than two separate, complete radioactive 
decay life-cycles". Furthermore, no process has ever been observed that 
effects the decay rate sufficiently enough to make dating methods based on 
half-lifes unviable.

2. Your 2nd comment - "The problem with all current dating methods..."
The following is a list of dating methods used in addition to radiometric 
dating:
Cosmogenic Nuclide Geochronology
Luminescence dating
Incremental dating
Magnetostratigraphy
Correlation of marker horizons
Are ALL of these methods flawed in your estimation, or is it just 
radiometric dating that you feel is wrong? More damaging to your position 
is the use of carbon dating on items of a known age and the accuracy of the 
results. I must add, before you attempt to imply that this is a stupid 
argument because the testers knew the age of the item and therefore just 
claimed that the results were accurate; I would sincerely recommend doing 
some unbiased research into radiometric dating methodology.

3. Your 3rd comment - "Evolve: to change or develop slowly often into a 
better, more complex, or more advanced state..."

biology.about.com
Biological evolution is defined as any genetic change in a population that 
is inherited over several generations. These changes may be small or large, 
noticeable or not so noticeable.
In order for an event to be considered an instance of evolution, changes 
have to occur on the genetic level of a population and be passed on from 
one generation to the next.

freedictionary.com
Evolution
3. Biology
a. Change in the genetic composition of a population during successive 
generations, as a result of natural selection acting on the genetic 
variation among individuals, and resulting in the development of new 
species.

biology-online.org
Evolution
(1) The change in genetic composition of a population over successive 
generations, which may be caused by natural selection, inbreeding, 
hybridization, or mutation.

There is no "requirement" for evolution to produce organisms with increased 
complexity.
Adaptation is a process of natural selection.
Quote: "...the silver fox is incapable of producing healthy offspring when 
mingled with the same genes as its' progenitors due to degredation and 
modifications in the breed that have caused incompatibility..."
That would be a nice example of a speciation event, the inability to 
procreate with its own "kind" (Did someone say Macro-evolution...)

More in part 2 tomorrow...

----- 2 DAYS LATER -----

I do not have the time (nor the patience to type an essay on my phone); the

you have clearly evidenced in just the comments in this thread an almost

I will finish this post here for tonight; the actual debunking shall 
commence tommorow...

It's NOT a religion. A religion is belief through faith without actual 
provable facts. Evolution is observable. If it wasn't, scientists would not 
accept it as it is today. Like I said, when a theory fails, science 
discards it, because it can no longer function properly and make 
predictions for the future. Opposed to to religion, who keep clinging on to 
disproven "facts" that simply do  not hold up to the experiments. 
Constantly trying to wiggle around to make their claims work in their 
favour. The funniest thing about it, is that when religion is trying to 
make a point they will use science to do it, but when the science does not 
add up to their claims, they simply say the science is flawed and 
untrustworthy.

I might even take the liberty of going so far as to say that Evolution is 
the common religion of most scientists because it frees them from whatever 
restrictions morality, traditional society, and more established religions 
might impose on them. In theory, that may not necessarily be a bad thing... 
but again, I would point to the quantity of discoveries we have unlocked 
since evolution began making significant progress invading into modern 
cultures as evidence that may suggest that it is not as helpful as 
originally thought. Perhaps more tests are needed, or a better control 
group need be found.

It is entirely possible to refute "logic" as you suggested it with 
terminology, as the terms are the product of logic, not the inverse. Terms 
are crafted because the need for differing terms for differing 
phenomenon/objects and what have you was deemed necessary. It is very 
simple wwwelkman, I've said it twice now and I will say it yet again.

Evolution by definition requires that increased complexity is necessary for 
something to be evolutionary. Adaptation does not require increases in 
complexity, and always has a purpose for happening (namely, addressing 
a deficiency, where evolution does not).  I don't have to tell you exactly 
what the difference is, but just because I can take part of the same route 
to get to completely different destinations does not make my route the same 
both times. That is pretty stupid thinking if you believe that that is the 
case, because I can assure you, that while the route from California 
to Florida, and the route from California to Texas may be the same for a 
while.. the final destinations are drastically different.

Terminology is not an excuse for anything, it is about accuracy. The whole 
premise of the "big bang" or whatever you want to call that silly idea is 
lousy no matter what term you apply, it isn't about the term in that 
case. In reference to your question ZyneXx, my argument is that Evolution 
is not factual as many have been touting, and is arguable whether or not 
the term Theory is even properly applied. To a degree, I feel Evolution is 
being VERY improperly pushed as being true or factual when in reality that 
is far from accurate.

Hypothesis: A proposition, or set of propositions, set forth as an 
explanation for the occurrence of some specified group of phenomena, either 
asserted merely as a provisional conjecture to guide investigation (working 
hypothesis)  or accepted as highly probable in the light of established 
facts.

Theory: a coherent group of tested general propositions, commonly regarded 
as correct, that can be used as principles of explanation and prediction 
for a class of phenomena: 

or

A proposed explanation whose status is still conjectural and subject to 
experimentation, in contrast to well-established propositions that are 
regarded as reporting matters of actual fact.

Both of those terms would fit Evolution, but fact most certainly does not. 
My argument is primarily about the factual (or more particularly in this 
case, lack thereof) nature of Evolution vs Creation. In all reality, if we 
want to be honest about it... both the Theory of Evolution and Creationism 
rely primarily on faith and educated guessing at the core. It troubles me 
how many people seem to think that Evolution is scientific, when really it 
has little or no basis in science, but rather has become something that 
many "scientists" attempt to make science fit rather than the other way 
around as it should be. Evolution thus far is a farce, and the failure to 
consider other options is a disservice to the world, to science, and a 
disgrace to any "scientist" who cannot be objective enough to consider more 
options than just the one that fits their agenda. In truth, Science is very 
limited and must be acknowledged as such before it can actually be useful 
for discovery. I fear this is part of the reason we have discovered so 
little in the past 50+ years or so.. we have mostly been refining what we 
learned from scientists before us for half a century. I am not suggesting 
we have discovered nothing, but I can say that we have actually discovered 
very few new scientific laws since the generation of Einstein passed away 
(about 10 discoveries, the majority of which were based upon ideas/research 
that was started by Einstein and his contemporaries).

We have not had a shortage in brilliant minds.. just quite a number of 
brilliant minds who seem overly distracted with trying to prove completely 
unrelated theories instead of doing what their predecessors did... find 
problems and solve them rather than find problems and attempt to find or 
craft solutions that fit into their view of the universe. I find/feel there 
is more of a disconnect between both the masses understanding of science, 
and the "scientists" truthfulness to the products and processes of good 
science. It looks/feels like most scientists are just another arm to any 
number of different propaganda machines on various sides of various issues 
when the only thing that should ultimately matter is the accuracy of facts, 
not what conclusions one can attempt to make from them even. A good 
experiment should yield good, factual evidence, not "good results". "Good 
results" suggest a likely bias, which is assured to be part of the basis of 
questionable science. Any result that yields verifiable information is a 
good result, not just ones that agree with the original hypothesis in 
testing. If all results are not published, I would say it is fair to 
question the honesty of the publisher and/or the scientist who recorded 
them. So in summation, my beef is with what I believe is more of a 
disservice to science and the world by scientists who refuse to simply test 
nature to see how it works in favor of attempting to see how they can make 
things fit into their notions of how our universe operations. The 
differentiation is relatively subtle, but very important as it is a 
fundamental difference in approach that tends to cause diluted and/or 
polluted results.

+wwwelkam  You are incorrect. I quoted you the actual meanings of the words.
Adaption is not random as it **ALWAYS** occurs to address a need or 
deficiency. If you don't believe me, look at the dictionary like I did to 
make sure.. you are wrong.

Evolution is also not necessarily random as it by definition (once again, 
feel free to look at the dictionary to see that you are wrong if you like) 
requires increased complexity to be considered evolution.

Modifications to a thing that result in reduced complexity or capacity are 
called mutations which also by definition are both negative, and always a 
defect that inhibits or reduces likelihood of survival/survivability.

Science and terminology are the most important places in which to 
understand your semantics. Terms are created for things for a reason.. they 
would not exist if they did not have a specific reason, as of all people; 
scientists are the most picky about terminology and the importance thereof. 
I suppose technical persons fall into that category as well, because 
similar things are not the same, else there would not be two terms.

+wwwelkam Scientists also once said that gravity was impossible to overcome 
and leaving the Earth was impossible.They also once said the Earth was 
Flat, The Sun rotated the Earth, and that nothing in the universe can be 
created or destroyed... and yet the same "scientists" who say that atomic 
decay rates cannot be modified now say that nothing can somehow explode 
into something... And some people think I'm an idiot? >.<

I'm not saying that to disparage you wwwelkam, but atomic decay can be 
changed just like everything else. All you have to do is change the 
variables just like every other mathematical equation. However, while the 
chance of decay is constant.. the rates however are not because radioactive 
decay is by nature stochastic (ie. random). Basically, every atom has a 
differing decay rate that cannot plausibly be used to judge another due to 
the fact that radioactive decay rates are random even amongst the same 
elements. The only constant in atomic decay is that the possibility or 
chance of atomic decay to occur at all is always the same. Atomic half-life 
isn't even scientific at all (excepting the fact it references atoms 
generally), but rather it is a term for a mathematical averaging of the 
time required to achieve the likelihood that somewhere around half of the 
quantity of a substance will experience radioactive decay. IE, we're 
working with quite A LOT of inaccuracy, averaging, and generality when 
we're talking about atomic half-life. None of those things is remotely 
suggestive of being able to determine anything with any certainty, since 
we're literally talking about a mathematical probability equation.. not a 
temporal measure based upon any kind of reliable, repeatable fact. Once 
again, unless we assume that nothing has in the past, or ever will in the 
future have any effect on atomic particles; we cannot presume that the 
estimated half-lives of various substances is even a plausible candidate 
for attempting to measure time.

+tirendir TL;DR How evolution works: Random changes with natural selection. 

How adaptation works: Random changes with natural selection.

Evolve: to change or develop slowly often into a better, more complex, or 
more advanced state : to develop by a process of evolution

Adapt : to change (something) so that it functions better or is better 
suited for a purpose

So no, adaptation and evolution are not the same. Evolution requires 
increasing complexity while adaptation does not. Evolving also requires 
certain progress, where the adapting of a breed to a particular environment 
does not make them more advanced.. it simply makes them better suited for 
one environment while they would be more likely to fail in others. That is 
not evolution by definition, no greater complexity or advancement of state 
was gained.. only a situation-specific change that is only necessarily 
beneficial in that specific situation. The Silver Fox is still a Fox.... It 
was never (and still isn't) anything besides a fox. Evolution is not a 
fact, as it has never been recorded before. A Fact is nothing more than 
first-hand verified information. A Fact is not what some scientist thinks 
about the hard facts, nor are what scientists translations of collected 
information actually facts. Facts are the records of  "I observed that this 
happened" and nothing more. Everything past that point is no longer 
factual, but is a different part of the scientific method. Evolution is an 
unproven and untested hypothesis, as it has never been observed and 
therefor appropriately not recorded. The breeding of dogs into different 
breeds is also not evolution.. that is simply breeding and tailoring for 
specific traits.. however it is actually a degradation, because to breed 
traits of a creature.. the preceding creatures must have had more traits 
than the one that is being bred. Ere-go that is actually a reduction of 
complexity and actually a complete opposite of evolution just as the Silver 
Fox is of its' parent foxes. The parent fox is not the reason they cannot 
breed.. the silver fox is incapable of producing healthy offspring when 
mingled with the same genes as its' progenitors due to degredation and 
modifications in the breed that have caused incompatibility (likely as a 
natural defense against predators who would easily pick off unsuited 
offspring that would likely also compromise the otherwise healthy and well 
adjusted parents).

And no, modern dating methods are not reliable as they rely on assumptions 
that cannot be proven for many millennia and anyone who would rely on such 
presumption is foolish. That is an egregious breach in scientific 
methodology. Until we have successfully observed the entirety of a minimum 
of no less than two separate, complete radioactive decay life-cycles.. we 
cannot have any way of verifying the accuracy of the claims regarding them. 
We have no way of knowing if they decay rates speed up drastically near the 
end... or if they are faster at the beginning, or that certain atomic 
reactions (or lack thereof) cause different behavior because we have not 
yet had the time to test all of those things on any single specimen. The 
long and short, while mathematically we can get a pretty fair idea about 
the timespan required for radioactive decay for certain elements.. we have 
to guess and presume that the decay rate that we have studied (which is a 
small fraction of the whole) is constant and always has been before we can 
even consider using it as a dating mechanism. The problem again, is that we 
have no way of knowing that fact since even the oldest recorded history 
that we can verify with actual calendars or solar events is no more than 
around 5000-6000 years old. Was there time before that? quite possibly.. 
but we have no way of knowing for certain because Science is not a tool for 
History or determining it. Science is a tool for the present that is only 
useful for helping to better predict or discern happenings in the future, 
and to better understand our universe. It however, cannot tell us the 
past.. that is what History is for. Don't forget or mistake folks, Science 
is useless without first-hand observation (History). I would point out.. no 
one has ever said that those who fail to understand science are doomed to 
repeat it (while we should pretty much all know that has been said of 
History). Science is not historical, though it can use History. History 
however cannot use Science. Science may help us better understand our 
History.. but it cannot tell us anything more than History has already done 
so.

+tirendir Have you ever taken physics class? Nothing can speed up or 
decrease the speed of atomic decay.

The problem with all current dating methods is that they are all based on a 
faulty (in this case, unproven and for the foreseeable future, impossible 
to prove premise). How many times have we seen the full lifespan of any 
atomic particle used for dating? The answer is very simple.. zero. Until we 
can actually verify that the actual time required for radioactive decay is 
X (rather than mathematically crunching the numbers based upon presuming 
the current measured rate of 1/1,000th of the span is constant for all of 
eternity prior and later).. it's no more than an educated guess in all 
actuality. Predictive science is all well and good, but it both cannot and 
should not be relied upon until the hypothesis can be proven (which I it 
has and cannot for some thousands of years).

I'm not saying the theory/hypothesis isn't necessarily sound.. but 
proclaiming calculations based upon assumptive hypothesis with extremely 
small testing quantities is an egregious failure in the usage of the 
scientific method.

Also you have to know how to use them. If you use uranium-lead dating on 
cracked zircon crystal and get strange date then it is your fault not the 
dating method.

Yes thank you. Both the K-Ar and Rb-Sr methods make use of radioactive 
decay of a parent isotope to a stable daughter isotope. But I will have to 
re-read the paper I got it from. In any case, the methods are accurate.

I used to be a creationist. I'd say my worldview was altered significantly.

I personally found both Nye and Ham make good counterpoints to each other. 
However, I also found that the fundamental difference between Nye and Ham 
in their positions on the issue at hand lies in their approaching of the 
existing and tangible evidence they have to work with.

Simply put, Ken Ham uses inductive reasoning, which I define as "the 
interpreting of evidence to further support a preconceived idea or 
explanation." Using the Bible and his interpretation of it as his starting 
points, he uses the facts to justify or exemplify his position.
In contrast, Bill Nye uses deductive reasoning, meaning he starts with the 
facts and, using only the facts, he builds an understanding that is further 
refined or revised completely based on new information that may arise.﻿

As an atheist/evolutionist, I'll tell you my opinion on who won: Ken Ham. 
Why? Let me explain. 
Ken Ham had common sense and emotions on his side whereas Bill Nye had 
science and evidence on his. 
If you ever wanna understand something, you gotta be able to relate to it. 
If you wanna relate to something, you gotta connect it to an emotion, 
feeling, experience, etc. This is why much of quantum mechanics and 
cosmology are so hard to understand. Much of what scientists discover in QM 
and cosmology are out of the ordinary and we cannot relate it to our 
everyday experiences.

emotions. This allowed the audience to understand what he was saying.

experimentation, and peer-review which is very difficult to understand.

real science and counter-intuitive reasoning - something creationists can't

there are other branes which could support "other universes".This is unlike 
the universes in the "quantum multiverse", but both concepts can operate at 
the same time.

The biggest mistake is to debate "religion" with "science"... everyone does 
this.

The debate should be "intelligent design" VS "science"... or better yet, 
"intelligent design" VS "myriad of accidents". Evolution is one smart 
mother fucker. And genetic mutations don't bring forth creative and precise 
results. Something as complex as DNA can't even fall together on it's own, 
even given 14 billion years; it's not mathematically possible, the odds 
aren't there. ﻿

+LeukickEDM
This is just wishful thinking.  There is no evidence for ID that can be 
tested, quantified, measured, or falsified, just as there is no evidence 
for a god.  That takes it out of the realm of science and into the realm of 
belief.  Believing something doesn't make it true.  Evdience determines 
whether something is true or not, which means science will always win any 
debate on this subject.  You cannot make truth claims, then try to alter 
facts to fit those claims.  It actually works the other way around.

+LeukickEDM "Intelligent Design is the most obvious thing in the universe.."
I am guessing you didn't anything above a high school education. 
Intelligent design is an excuse to explain things to complex to understand 
and starts as a bottom up approach, which by itself is unscientific and 
therefore the theory is mocked by 99% of the scientific community. It 
assumes religious texts are correct, which by definition makes no room for 
improvement or change, yet another unscientific attribute. Intelligent 
design isn't even supported by major religious institutions, the very place 
the theory took inspiration from! Evolution is a scientific theory subject 
to change, and so far has the most convincing argument. The only point 
creationist can argue is "the world is to complex to be created by mere 
accident" that stance is also very weak, as it has no proof supporting it 
and really is just laziness and complacency because they gave up trying to 
figure out the universes complexity and went for the "god did it, the end" 
answer. In other words the so called "theory" of intelligent design is 
based on opinion.

+Julie Paterson
Intelligent Design is the most obvious thing in the universe; look at 
yourself-- for one. Contrary to popular belief, ID actually does have some 
evidence to support it. And science isn't just fact; it also includes many, 
many theories, and is still very limited. The theory of evolution was 
started by some dude (the lovely Charles Darwin) well before we understood 
just how complex and sophisticated cells are... that says a lot. Theory of 
Evolution also suggests that any creative and purposeful function that 
appears to be Intelligent Design is due to genetic mutation. Genetic 
mutation actually doesn't, hasn't, and can't create anything-- there also 
isn't a single case of genetic mutation actually bringing about anything; 
it is however, known to cause damage... not purposeful genetic functions. 
It is also proven that DNA -- even the most basic form of it-- couldn't 
have fallen together on it's own by chance, given 14 billion years... it 
isn't mathematically possible because the odds aren't there. DNA is quite 
complex, it's pretty much a language.

Realistically speaking, egos and biases aside, do you really think 
everything in the entire universe, is an absolute myriad of accidents, 
despite being alarmingly precise? Literally everything is SO precise.. when 
you look into it, it actually becomes blatantly obvious of ID, there just 
isn't enough "proof" (lol) to call it "fact", because no one will even 
consider it because they associate "God" with "a man in the sky". The truth 
is hidden (on purpose). Both Atheists and religious people don't even 
realize. There's much more that I can say...

'Intelligent design' or 'creation' shouldn't even be mentioned in the same 
sentence as science.  Science depends on facts, the other is merely a 
belief, with no evidence backing it up.  Facts are always facts.  The 
science behind the Theory of Evolution is well established, there is no 
science that can support ID.  ID fails, bigtime!

Definition from the United States Academy of Sciences 

The formal scientific definition of theory is quite different from the 
everyday meaning of the word. It refers to a comprehensive explanation of 
some aspect of nature that is supported by a vast body of evidence. Many 
scientific theories are so well established that no new evidence is likely 
to alter them substantially. For example, no new evidence will demonstrate 
that the Earth does not orbit around the sun (heliocentric theory), or that 
living things are not made of cells (cell theory), that matter is not 
composed of atoms, or that the surface of the Earth is not divided into 
solid plates that have moved over geological timescales (the theory of 
plate tectonics)...One of the most useful properties of scientific theories 
is that they can be used to make predictions about natural events or 
phenomena that have not yet been observed.[7]

So it usually has to meet the below

It makes falsifiable predictions with consistent accuracy across a broad 
area of scientific inquiry (such as mechanics).

It is well-supported by many independent strands of evidence, rather than a 
single foundation. This ensures that it is probably a good approximation, 
if not completely correct.

It is consistent with pre-existing theories and other experimental results. 
(Its predictions may differ slightly from pre-existing theories in cases 
where they are more accurate than before.)

It can be adapted and modified to account for new evidence as it is 
discovered, thus increasing its predictive capability over time.

It is among the most parsimonious explanations, sparing in proposed 
entities or explanations. (See Occam's razor. Since there is no generally 
accepted objective definition of parsimony, this is not a strict criterion, 
but some theories are much less economical than others.)

 Thank you for applying words better than I can.
I don't know why people think theory means guess or 'this is how it works,

Maybe it's trying to use simple words to discredit things, however it would

As has been repeatedly stated, this boils down to an issue of definition of 
terminology; the addition of understanding of those definitions being the 
disconnect. The aquatic ape hypothesis has not been sufficiently backed up 
by empirical evidence and, as a result, is only a hypothesis. The theory of 
evolution, on the other hand, is one of the most well supported scientific 
theories we have. At this point I should present the evidence which 
justifies this statement. The problem with doing so is where to start. Just 
DNA alone provides evidence of the fact that evolution occurs. 
To clarify the situation with evolution within scientific discourse:
It is established as fact (to the extent that anything in science can be) 
that evolution occurs.
How evolution happens; the processes involved and their mechanisms - this 
is what we refer to as the theory of evolution. These processes, 
particularly the significance of their involvement, has not been 
sufficiently proven enough to allow us to categorically state specifically 
what is and is not relevant to evolutionary progress.
I will add that the above explaination was based on my own thoughts without 
reference to other sources during its composition. I feel it reasonably 
represents the distinction between the fact and theory.

Here are a few examples taken from scientific journals that have either 
used potassium- argon and dated much lower than your two million years, or 
where many methods were used and found to be severely anomalous. As you 
read through them, please try to think about which system we should accept 
when the same specimen does date so differently from one system to the 
next. If you need more I can post more.

Allende
Even with all the assumptions of the evolutionists, these systems fail 
miserably. The dates of different methods usually don’t match as in the 
Meteorite  ”Allende”.  Pb-207/Pb206=4.5 billion years  Pb207/u-235=5.57 
billion years  Pb-206/U238=8.82 billion years  pb-208/T-232=10.4 billion 
years  Sr-87/Sr86=4.48 billion years.  In all the various methods of 
testing on over 50 inclusions of Allende, the scatter ranged from 
3.91-16.49 billion years.

Allende-  Study by T Kirsten, 1980 discussed in The Chemical Evolution of 
the Atmosphere and Ocean, by Heinrich D Holland, 1984, Princeton University 
Press,  p.6.
Gale, N., et al. “ Uranium-Lead Chronology of Chrondite Meteorites,” Nature 
(Physical Sciences),  Vol 240, Nov. 20, 1972 
Tatsumoto, M. Unrch, D., and Desborough,G., “U-Th-Pb and Rb- Sr Systemetics 
of Allende and U-Th-PB Systematics of Orgueil,” Geochemica et Chosmochemica 
Acta, Vol 40, 1976,p. 616-634

Hualalai Volcano, Hawaii
Kaupelehu flow, Hualalai Volcano, erupted 18-1801. Several different 
minerals and inclusions and a variety of methods. 12 dates recorded range 
from 140 mil to 2.96 billion years.
Funkhouser, John G., and Naughton, John J., Radiogenic Helium and Argon in 
Ultramafic Inclusions from Hawaii,” Journal of Geophysical research, Vol. 
73, No.14, July,1968, pp.4601-4607

Salt Lake Crater, Oahu Hawaii
Salt Lake Crater, Oahu Hawaii. One method produced an age of less than 
400,000 years old, but the other sixteen ranged from 2.6 million to 3.3 
billion with the average age of 845 million. Funkhouser, John G., and 
Naughton, John J., Radiogenic Helium and Argon in Ultramafic Inclusions 
from Hawaii,” Journal of Geophysical research, Vol. 73, No.14, July,1968, 
pp.4601-4607

Sunset Crater, Northern Arizona
Sunset Crater, Northern Arizona. Indian artifacts found in the rocks 
created by the eruption. Tree ring dated eruption accurately at 1065 years 
A.D. Two lava flows were dated at 210,000 and 230,000 using potassium 
–argon method.  Dalrymple, G. B. “40 Ar/36 Ar Analysis of Historical Lava 
flows,” Earth and Planetary letters,  Vol .  6, 1969 ,pp. 47-55

Mt Rangitoto in New Zealand
 The eruption of Mt. Rangitoto in New Zealand dated trees destroyed  by the 
eruption to be less than 300 years old using radio carbon, but the 
Potassium-Argon method dated the eruption at 485,000 years. Mc Dougall, I. 
et al, “Excess Radiogenic Argon in young Subearial Basalts from Aukland 
Volcanic Field, New Zealand,” Geochemica et Chosmochemica Acta, vol. 33 
1969, pp. 1485-1520

Vulcan’s Throne Volcano, Grand Canyon
Vulcan’s Throne Volcano, Grand Canyon. Potassium- argon dated the eruption 
at 10,000 years, but Native American legends recall the eruption of 
volcanoes in this area. The Indians have been in this area a few thousand 
years at most.  Reynolds, S. J., et al., “ Compilation of Radiometric Age 
 Determination
 in Arizona,”  Arizona Bureau of Geology and Mineral Technology bulletin 
197, 1968, p.8.

 Still at Vulcan’s throne the mineral olivine contained in the lava flow 
was tested. It showed a date of 117+/-3 million years.  Damon, P.E. and 
others, “Correlation and Chronology of the Ore Deposits and Volcanic 
Rocks,” US Energy Commission Annual Report, No, C00-689-76, 1967, p. 82.

dated using potassium-argon (same flow). The real date should be zero or 
“to young to date”. At 4680m it was dated at 21 +/- 8 million years.  At 
3420m 12+/- 2 million years,  and at 1400m a date of zero.

pp.265-266

As in other genomes, the DNA of the human genome is not a static entity. 
Instead, it is subject to a variety of different types of heritable change 
(otherwise known as mutation). Large-scale chromosome abnormalities involve 
loss or gain of chromosomes or breakage and rejoining of chromatids. 

Smaller scale mutations can be grouped into different mutation classes and 
can also be categorized on the basis of whether they involve a single DNA 
sequence or whether they involve exchanges between two allelic or 
nonallelic sequences. Three classes of small-scale mutation can be 
distinguished.

These small scale mutations are Base substitutions, Deletions, and 
Insertions. So basically, yes information is "dropped off" sometimes, but 
DNA is never degraded... DNA changes over time THUS evolution.

Ok i'm going to explain very simply how evolution makes something like the 
eye happen.

The survival of the most adaptable is usually favored. This means the 
creature most able to live and procreate in its surroundings compared to 
those who are not adapted will have more of a chance to pass on its genetic 
code.

If a creature has favorable traits it will breed more (have more 
opportunity to breed due to its advantages), the mediocre will breed a 
mediocre amount, and the vastly underwhelming will die off quickly not 
having a chance to breed. This is not in ALL cases but a statistical 
majority large enough to allow for positive adaptable change to happen.

The genes are passed on over time and traits which favor survivability win 
out over lesser traits. The eye in all it's complexity is a series of very 
simple advances.

The earliest predecessors of the eye were photo receptor proteins that 
sense light. over time small mutations allowing better ways to view the 
visible light spectrum won out. If you want a FULL and detailed look at the 
evolution of the eye see the link below.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_the_eye

What I am not ok with is the projection of mathematical models back in time 
without any variables considered, and then taking that as "proof". Anyone 
can take a logarithmic function (which is the basis of carbon dating and 
other forms of radioactive decay that involve the solution from a 
differential equation) and make predictions about tests and there will 
still be experimental error even in a controlled situation, yet we have no 
controls about what has happened in the past and yet we should accept these 
models are accurate predictions of our planet's past?

I say these things, because evolution should not be taken as fact without 
question. The laws of physics, thermodynamics, and countless other laws can 
be 100% proven by the scientific method, yet evolution can't be because we 
only view adaptations. And the "evolving of viruses" are still only 
changing to survive, not changing into a new species or classification. 

Evolution is becoming a religion to people. They cling to its falsities as 
truth, and are missing the real truth, God's Word. I can only urge you to 
read it and apply it to your life, read how it can enrich your life, and 
lead to salvation and peace of mind. This is why I argue, for your 
salvation, not for proving a point or winning an argument, because it 
doesn't matter, the only thing that matters is your heart and opening it to 
the truth.

found to back proof of Jesus Christ walking this planet. Being Created 
makes more sense than Evolution telling us that one tiny, little bacteria

emotion-filled heart! That's my take.. Bill Nye mentioned close to the end

I think that, since 46% of Americans don't laugh Ken Ham right off the 
stage means that what we're doing isn't working. Not in America, anyway. I 
think Bill Nye did great, not for debate performance (although that was 
good also, just not important), but how he engaged the audience. It's about 
how he challenged them to become scientists and prove him wrong, if 
possible. He then outlined exactly how they could prove him wrong. Ken, 
just kept saying "read the bible" then you'll know "everything" just like I 
do. I think that the "don't give them any street cred by debating them" 
attitude just makes us look like a bunch of scared, weak, little pencil 
necks and we need to knock that off, right now! I think the proof is in how 
ABYSMAL our performance has been in politics. Bill Nye, like myself, is 
"only" and Engineer. You don't need any more than 10th grade biology to 
understand and support these concepts, let alone 4 years of dedicated study 
(or eight for a PHD). These PHD's (you know who you are) need to start 
pulling their weight. We need more of these debates, not less, and what 
that "lowly" Engineer did should be the model.  Don't engage the nut, reach 
out to the audience. It's just that simple.  Reach out to the young, 
inquisitive minds, and show them how you're opinion, unlike the 
creationist, is completely testable. Challenge them to do that work for 
themselves. Kids respond to that, (college age is still a kid, you kids 
will see that, for yourselves, soon enough), they don't respond to being 
told what to think. The facts are on OUR side. Let's always remember that 
and just politely and patiently present them, to the audience and not the 
nut job we're arguing with, as Bill Nye (the "Engineer") did. I liked the 
debate. Those who say that it didn't go well for us, no matter which side 
of this issue you're on, were watching a different debate than I.﻿
